title: 103_hr358
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement Act." Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that law enforcement officers face increasing challenges in the war against drugs and crime, with a lack of support from the Federal Government. The rate of violent crime is rising, along with drug use, and a significant number of arrested individuals test positive for drugs. A review of law enforcement issues, including drug-related crime, violence, racial conflict, and funding, is necessary. The Federal Government's role in supporting law enforcement officers, working conditions, and crime control needs to be redefined to improve relationships with the public and officials. Establishment of the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement" and its duties. The Commission will study and recommend changes regarding law enforcement agencies and issues at Federal, State, and local levels, including funding, employment conditions, information-sharing systems, research and training, equipment and resources, cooperation among agencies, government and agency responsibility in solving crime, and the impact of the criminal justice system. The Commission will conduct surveys and consult with law enforcement officers, officials, and community leaders nationwide to gather information on key law enforcement issues. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 25 members, including individuals from national law enforcement organizations representing officers and management. Appointments are made by various leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. Members include individuals with academic expertise in law enforcement, Members of Congress, and individuals from federal law enforcement agencies. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. One individual from the Department of Justice, appointed by the President, and three individuals representing State or local governmental entities will be appointed by various officials. The Comptroller General will oversee the methodology of the Commission's study, and members will select a chairperson. Members will not receive additional compensation for their service on the Commission. Members of the Commission will not receive additional compensation for their service, but will receive travel expenses. They must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission may hire experts and consultants as needed. Federal agencies can provide personnel to assist the Commission upon request. The General Services Administrator will offer administrative support services to the Commission as requested. The Commission is granted powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission, as outlined in Section 7, has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, delegate authority, obtain information from federal agencies, accept gifts and donations, and use the United States mails. Additionally, the Commission is required to submit a report as per Section 8. The Commission, established under Section 7, has the authority to conduct hearings, gather evidence, and submit a report within eighteen months to Congress with legislative proposals. It will terminate sixty days after submitting the report, and certain titles from previous acts will be repealed.
